abstract: Background: The World Health Organization defined a ‘screen and vaccinate’ strategy as its recommended policy for the licensed dengue vaccine (Dengvaxia, Sanofi Pasteur), so that only individuals with previous dengue infection are vaccinated. The objectives of the present study were to build upon a recently published analysis of the benefits and risks associated with dengue vaccination to evaluate the public health impact and cost-effectiveness of a screen and vaccinate strategy. Methods: The current analysis was based on a previously reported transmission model and added, for the screening part, three rapid diagnostic tests with identical specificity (99%) but alternative sensitivities (50-70-90%) in the detection of prior dengue infection. The impact of a screen-and-vaccinate strategy considered nine settings representing different levels of transmission intensity. Outcomes (dengue-related hospitalizations, severe dengue, and symptomatic dengue) were assessed according to the level of transmission setting. The cost-effectiveness of vaccination in 10 endemic countries was also assessed. Results: Although associated, in most cases, with a lower population impact than a ‘no-screening’ approach, a screen and vaccinate strategy is more effective in reducing the number of hospitalized and severe cases prevented per vaccination performed and generates positive health benefits for individuals screened and subsequently vaccinated. As a result, this intervention is cost-effective in all countries considered except for very low transmission settings. The overall population impact of a screen and vaccinate approach is also likely to be improved by the use of several rounds of screening (up to 48% reduction in dengue hospitalization over 10 years with 5 rounds). Conclusions: WHO recommended option of a screen and vaccinate policy is likely to have a positive impact both at the individual and population level across a wide range of transmission settings and has the potential to be as, if not more, cost-effective than a no screening strategy.

author_highlights.sentence: A tetravalent dengue vaccine has been licenced for use in several countries.
The WHO defined a ‘screen and vaccinate’ strategy as its recommended option.
Screen and vaccinate is beneficial at individual/population level in most settings.
Population impact can be improved by the use of several rounds of screening.
The cost-effectiveness is as good, if not better, than a ‘no screening’ strategy.

body_text.sentence: Based on these results, three RDT test characteristic profiles were chosen to reflect both current and possible future test performance, i.e. an ‘RDT 70%’ scenario corresponding to a screening test for which the sensitivity was set at 70% and the specificity at 99%, and an ‘RDT 90%’ and ‘RDT50%’ for which sensitivities were set at 90% and 50%, respectively while maintaining high specificity (99%).

body_text.sentence: DSS was involved in the design of the economic analysis, the interpretation of data and critical review of the scientific content.
body_text.title: Authors’ contributions

body_text.sentence: There are no specific treatments for dengue and past efforts have focused on vector control, which have proved difficult to implement and maintain [4–7].
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: Here, we specifically focus on the potential impact of various screen and vaccinate strategies to provide insights on the public health and economic value of such strategies for a range of transmission settings.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: The same 80% coverage rate described in the preceding paragraph was also used for each of the screening rounds implemented for multi-round screening strategies.
body_text.title: Modelling outcomes

body_text.sentence: In addition, we considered the potential for seroscreening (in line with WHO recommended policy) using data from hypothetical serological point of care tests, both with very high specificity to ensure an optimal selection of true seropositive individuals and with two levels of sensitivity.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: This corresponds to a situation enabling those who tested negative during the first screening round, and were therefore either not vaccinated, or screened during previous rounds, to be screened two years later and be vaccinated if they then tested positive.
body_text.title: Modelling outcomes

body_text.sentence: The number of hospitalizations prevented per individual screened tends to decrease slightly as the number of screening rounds performed increases.
body_text.title: The value of repeated screening

body_text.sentence: The health system perspective incorporated the costs of purchasing vaccine and screening tests, test administration and vaccine delivery, and treatment of dengue cases as well as wastage for vaccines and screening tests.
body_text.title: Analysis of cost effectiveness

body_text.sentence: We also considered a wide range of possible outcomes, including the effects at individual and population levels, the optimal age for vaccination, the effects of repeated rounds of seroscreening, covering different age groups (between 9 and 21 years of age), and the cost-effectiveness of various approaches to give a comprehensive consideration of the likely impact of the various alternative scenarios and settings.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: In the median case, this price varied from $55 to $88 in transmission settings where ≥30% of 9-year-olds are seropositive.
body_text.title: Cost-effectiveness

body_text.sentence: We chose to consider a large variety of settings to provide general insights on the public health value and cost-effectiveness of a screen and vaccinate approach.
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: A live, attenuated, tetravalent vaccine was developed (CYD-TDV; Dengvaxia, Sanofi Pasteur) and has demonstrated its efficacy in two large-scale phase III trials involving over 30,000 participants in dengue endemic countries [9,10], and is licenced for use in individuals aged 9–45 years living in endemic areas in several countries.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: It is therefore likely that they can be developed further to improve performance in this indication to eventually match the performance reported for ELISA-based tests.
body_text.title: Model development

body_text.sentence: In response to these Sridhar et al. [11], the World Health Organization (WHO) supported by its Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunisation (SAGE) updated its position on the use of the dengue vaccine.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: In a recent follow-up meeting (the Global Dengue and Aedes-transmitted diseases Consortium [GDAC]) country representatives from Asia and Latin America discussed the many challenges associated with introducing CYD-TDV, acknowledging this vaccine faced more challenges than for any other vaccine introduction programme [18].
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: We also did not directly address specifically the feasibility aspects of a screen-and-vaccinate approach which could be complicated to implement since it differs from traditional immunization programs and could generate costs not covered in our analysis [18].
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: Results presented in Fig. 5 indicate that from a health system perspective, using a screen-and-vaccinate strategy with RDT 70% was cost-effective for all countries considered with a transmission setting where ≥30% of 9-year-olds are seropositive, and highly cost-effective from ≥50% for all countries except Vietnam and Honduras (Table S5).
body_text.title: Cost-effectiveness

body_text.sentence: Finally, we assessed the efficiency of repeated screening by calculating the number of hospitalizations prevented per individual screened and vaccinated according to the number of screening rounds (supplemental Fig. S2A and Fig. S2B).
body_text.title: The value of repeated screening

body_text.title: Modelling outcomes

body_text.sentence: As already mentioned in a previous cost-effectiveness analysis of dengue [19], which used a similar methodology to this study, the economic results presented here have to be considered with caution.
body_text.title: Discussion
